greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Smallest (i.e., rightmost) Lyndon word in the Lyndon factorization of the binary representation of n (written using 1's and 2's rather than 0's and 1's, since numbers > 0 in the OEIS cannot begin with 0).
comment: See A211095 and A211097 for further information, including Maple programs.
example: n=25 has binary expansion 11001, which has Lyndon factorization (1)(1)(001) with three factors. The rightmost factor is 001, which we write as a(25) = 112.
The real sequence (written with 0's and 1's rather than 1's and 2's) is:
results.author: _N. J. A. Sloane_, Mar 31 2012
